title: [DOC] Example with `yfinance` and its daily time series
body:
#### Describe the issue linked to the documentation

Currently the usage of a forecaster is vague,
https://github.com/ranaroussi/yfinance

Example data extraction
```python
!pip install yfinance
import yfinance as yf

msft = yf.Ticker("MSFT")
hist = msft.history(period="max")['Close'] # using closing price as univariate expression

X_train = hist[:-10] # training data, turns to NumPy array
X_test = hist[-10:].index # testing intervals as timestamps
# avoiding the use of temporal split
```
Right now if one hot-plugs 
```
forecaster.fit(X_train) # forecaster as anything derived by BaseForecaster

fh = ForecastingHorizon(X_test.index, is_relative=False)
X_test = forecaster.predict(fh) # futile with `asfreq('D')` conversion
```
You get `ValueError: Must supply freq for datetime value`

#### Suggest a potential alternative/fix

Some extra documentation on which forms of data is good for fitting and predicting, and in which format. Regarding `ForecastingHorizon` not much explanation has been made what it is and why it is necessary.
https://www.sktime.org/en/stable/get_started.html#forecasting

P.S.
- multivariate prediction has not been tested yet.
- [Pandas-Datareader's Yahoo API](https://pydata.github.io/pandas-datareader/readers/yahoo.html), [IEX API](https://pydata.github.io/pandas-datareader/readers/iex.html), and [Stooq API](https://pydata.github.io/pandas-datareader/readers/stooq.html#module-pandas_datareader.stooq) might be better?
